title: Dow down nearly 500 points as Fed decision looms over market; Treasury yields jump
text:
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA dropped 455 points, or 1.5%, to 30,557, after falling nearly 550 points earlier.

* The S&P 500 SPX was down 58 points, or 1.5%, at 3,841.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP declined 148 points, or 1.3%, to 11,389.

What's driving markets

The next Federal Open Market Committee decision is looming over the market, as investors grapple not just with whether the central bank will make a 75 basis point rate increase or lift rates by 100 points, but also how high the Fed will signal rates will go in the future. The meeting started Tuesday and will conclude on Wednesday.

In the interim, Callie Cox, U.S. investment analyst at eToro, said rising bond yields and a paucity of positive news have left U.S. equity benchmarks "wandering in no-man's-land" below their moving averages.

See: Why rising Treasury yields are plaguing the stock market ahead of Fed's next rate increase

"There isn't much to hang on to and when selling starts, it tends to pile up," Cox said.

Meanwhile, Treasury yields, which move opposite to price, continued to march higher, with the rate on the 10-year note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y jumping 6.5 basis points to 3.540% after ending Monday at its highest since 2011. The yield on the 2-year note BX:TMUBMUSD02Y continued to press toward the 4% threshold. Rising yields can weigh on stocks, making government bonds appear more attractive relative to riskier assets like equities.

"Stock markets always watch the bond markets and the 10 year is now above 3.5%," Cox added.

See: Why rising Treasury yields are a drag on the stock market

Of course, the Fed isn't the only major central bank hiking interest rates to fight stubbornly high inflation. Sweden's Riksbank on Tuesday opted for a 100 basis point hike, and analysts expect at least a half-point rise when the Bank of England meets Thursday.

European central banks were particularly on edge after producer prices in Germany increased by more than 45% in August compared with the same period a year ago, news that may also be influencing U.S. markets.

All 11 S&P 500 sectors were trading in the red on Tuesday, with real estate, materials and consumer discretionary shares seeing the biggest losses. As a result, the SPDR S&P Retail ETF XRT, Materials Select Sector SPDR Fund UK:XLBP and iShares U.S. Real Estate ETF IYR were all sharply lower.

The communications services sector is also on track to close at its lowest level since June 2020, which is largely a reflection of weakness in megacap tech stocks like Meta Platforms Inc. METAand Alphabet Inc. GOOGL, along with telecommunications giants like AT&T Inc. Tand Verizon Communications Inc. VZ

Data showed U.S. housing starts rose 12.2% in August after a revised 10.9% fall in July, while building permits dropped 10% in August.

Companies in focus

* Ford Motor Co. F late Monday said inflation and parts shortages will leave it with more unfinished vehicles than expected and that payments to suppliers will be about $1 billion more than expected. Ford did nonetheless reiterate its full-year operating profit outlook. Shares fell more than 11%.

* Apple Inc. AAPL announcedprice rises for the app store in a number of Asian and European countries, likely a response to the surge in the U.S. dollar DXY. Shares were up 0.7%. Apple and Boeing Company BAwere the only two Dow stocks clinging to gains Tuesday afternoon.

* Nordstrom Inc. JWN shares fell 1.9% after the department store chain said it adopted a shareholder rights plan, also known as a "poison pill," that is effective immediately and lasts for one year.
